articles.headline: Devices Lead the Way to a Smarter TV
articles.snippet: While change is coming to the television set, for now the best way to get access to online video is through game consoles and other devices like Apple TV and Google’s Chromecast.
articles.abstract: While change is coming to the television set, for now the best way to get access to online video is through game consoles and other devices like Apple TV and Google’s Chromecast.
articles.lead_paragraph: Someday, our televisions will be smart. With a flick of the wrist or a voice command, couch potatoes will be able to binge-view “Scandal” or children will watch any episode of the Disney series “Dog With a Blog.” Maybe just thinking about Walter White will bring up “Breaking Bad” on the big screen.

articles.headline: No Clarity From Fed on Stimulus, Upsetting Wall Street
articles.snippet: Fed watchers offered very different analyses after the minutes of the central bank’s July meeting were released, sending the stock market lower.
articles.abstract: Fed watchers offered very different analyses after the minutes of the central bank’s July meeting were released, sending the stock market lower.
articles.lead_paragraph: Will they move in September or won’t they?

articles.headline: The Voice-Off: Android vs. Siri
articles.snippet: Is speech recognition better on smartphones running Google’s operating system or Apple’s? That depends on how it’s used.
articles.abstract: Is speech recognition better on smartphones running Google’s operating system or Apple’s? That depends on how it’s used.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Your review was the dumbest thing I’ve ever read. It strains me to avoid profanity in describing how stupid you sound.”

articles.headline: Cyprus Bank’s Bailout Hands Ownership to Russian Plutocrats
articles.snippet: Months after the European Union bailout of Cyprus’s banks, Russian shareholders have become majority owners, at least on paper, of the country’s largest financial institution.
articles.abstract: Months after the European Union bailout of Cyprus’s banks, Russian shareholders have become majority owners, at least on paper, of the country’s largest financial institution.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — When European leaders engineered a harsh bailout deal for this tiny Mediterranean nation in March, they cheered the end of an economic model fueled by a flood of cash from Russia. Wealthy Russians with money in Cyprus’s sickly banks lost billions.

articles.headline: Secret Court Rebuked N.S.A. on Surveillance
articles.snippet: A 2011 ruling held that the N.S.A. had violated the Constitution for several years by gathering tens of thousands of domestic communications unrelated to terrorism.
articles.abstract: A 2011 ruling held that the N.S.A. had violated the Constitution for several years by gathering tens of thousands of domestic communications unrelated to terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge sharply rebuked the National Security Agency in 2011 for repeatedly misleading the court that oversees its surveillance on domestic soil, including a program that is collecting tens of thousands of domestic e-mails and other Internet communications of Americans each year, according to a secret ruling made public on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Scott Shane

articles.headline: China Boss’s Fall Puts Focus on a Business Ally
articles.snippet: Chinese officials are relying on evidence from Xu Ming, a businessman with close ties to the former Politburo member Bo Xilai.
articles.abstract: Chinese officials are relying on evidence from Xu Ming, a businessman with close ties to the former Politburo member Bo Xilai.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — For years, Xu Ming, once a little-known entrepreneur from northeastern China, worked his way into the good graces of the families of China’s political elite.

articles.headline: Shifting Tech Scene Unsettles Big Players
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard, Cisco and other companies that once dominated the industry are struggling as users turn to cloud computing services and mobile phones.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard, Cisco and other companies that once dominated the industry are struggling as users turn to cloud computing services and mobile phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Outsiders often think of Silicon Valley as a constantly changing landscape, a place where fortunes rise and fall with the next great idea. Now some of the technology industry’s biggest names are finding out that once you fall behind, it is pretty hard to catch up.

articles.headline: U.P.S. to End Health Benefits for Spouses of Some Workers
articles.snippet: In announcing a move that will affect about 15,000 employees, United Parcel Service cited costs associated with the federal health care law.
articles.abstract: In announcing a move that will affect about 15,000 employees, United Parcel Service cited costs associated with the federal health care law.
articles.lead_paragraph: United Parcel Service has told its white-collar employees that it will stop providing health care coverage to their spouses who can obtain coverage through their own employers, joining an increasing number of companies that are restricting or eliminating spousal health benefits.

articles.headline: Obama Officials Weigh Response to Syria Assault
articles.snippet: Amid a growing belief that chemical weapons were used in the attack, senior officials met at the White House on Thursday to debate options that could range from a cruise missile strike to a more sustained air campaign.
articles.abstract: Amid a growing belief that chemical weapons were used in the attack, senior officials met at the White House on Thursday to debate options that could range from a cruise missile strike to a more sustained air campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after a deadly assault in Syria that bore many of the hallmarks of a chemical weapons attack, a sharply divided Obama administration on Thursday began weighing potential military responses to President Bashar al-Assad’s forces.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Mark Mazzetti and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Muted Fears of Contagion as Asian Currencies Fall
articles.snippet: The nations most affected have been India and Indonesia, where many domestic and foreign investors are now rushing for the exits.
articles.abstract: The nations most affected have been India and Indonesia, where many domestic and foreign investors are now rushing for the exits.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — South and Southeast Asia are being buffeted by broad shifts in international economics, but with Japan and China to the north largely unaffected, fears of a more widespread crisis are being played down.

articles.headline: The Audacious Pragmatist
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke was a shy, methodical academic. But he turned out to be one of the most daring leaders in the Fed’s history — even if his goals have not been fully realized.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke was a shy, methodical academic. But he turned out to be one of the most daring leaders in the Fed’s history — even if his goals have not been fully realized.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHORTLY before Ben S. Bernanke was nominated as chairman of the Federal Reserve in 2005, he paid a return visit to Stanford, where he started his academic career in 1979. In a speech, he recalled that he and his wife, Anna, had rented a house with friends because he was certain that local real estate prices would fall. Instead, prices in the Bay Area doubled, then doubled again.
